prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have dedicated the upper side-bands to two manually placed, broad spectral windows (232.5 and 235 GHz). This is to maximise our bandwidth to ensure that we recover the continuum well.
In order to reliably recover the fragment mass distribution in our targets, we require accurate measurements of the dust temperature. At these extreme densities (> 10^7 cm^-3), we expect that the dust and gas will be thermalised (see e.g. Clark et al. 2013). We can therefore use estimated gas temperatures to infer dust temperatures and hence, dust mass.
To obtain reliable gas temperatures, we are using the lower side-bands to target the 3 lines of the para-H2CO transitions and the CH3CN J=12-11 K-ladder. Both of these transitions can be used as reliable temperature probes. Our team has proven experience in the application of radiative transfer modelling to the observed spectra (e.g. Zhang et al. 1998; Longmore et al. 2011; Ginsburg et al. submitted). To resolve and reliably fit the hyper-fine components of the CH3CN J=12-11 K-ladder, we require a spectral resolution of < 1 km/s. Our SMA data show line-widths of 1 - 5 km/s towards these cores, and we estimate that for a purely thermal distribution, the expected line-width is ~ 0.7 km/s. We therefore require a spectral resolution of ~ 0.7 km/s, such that we can reliably trace the hyper-fine structure of the CH3CN J=12-11 K-ladder, the relative velocities of the fragments, velocity gradients, signs of rotation and outflows. Indeed, Krumholz et al. (2007a) utilise mock ALMA observations to demonstrate that the CH3CN J=12--11 K-ladder can be used to detect rotation velocities of ~ 2 - 5 km/s with ALMA at this spatial scale.
In addition to the lines that we are specifically targeting, our spectral set-up has been selected to provide a combination of dense gas tracers (CH3CN, H2CO, CH3OH, OCS, SO), shocked/hot gas tracers (SiO, SO, HNCO) and outflow tracers (SiO, 13CO, C18O), plus a suite of other lines covered by our proposed base-bands.

We require an angular resolution of 0.13" as this corresponds to a physical scale of ~ 1000 AU at the distance of our sources (8.4 kpc). This scale is a predicted fragmentation size scale for the precursors to very massive stars (see e.g. Krumholz et al. 2007a; Commercon et al. 2011; Kuiper et al. 2011).
As these cores are very small (~ 5") and we expect to see sub-structure below this scale, we do not require use of the ACA.

Our requested RMS sensitivity is motivated by the brightness temperatures that we observe towards the cores in our sample with our SMA observations. The lines that we are targeting specifically (CH3CN, H2CO and SiO) are all detected with brightness temperatures > 6 K. We therefore request a sensitivity of 2 K such that, even in the worst-case scenario that the emission is uniformly distributed across the core, we will still detect the emission at a 3-sigma level in a 1 km/s channel. If the emission is not uniform and instead arises from discrete sub-structure within the cores, the emission will be significantly brighter and will therefore increase our signal-to-noise.
The corresponding continuum sensitivity is 15.33 uJy over an aggregate bandwidth of 5.6 GHz. The will provide high signal-to-noise detection of the 230 GHz dust continuum, and will allow to detect cores down to a (conservative) 5-sigma level of 0.1 Msun.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Extremely massive stars > 100 Msun are of great astrophysical importance. The huge amounts of energy and momentum that they inject into the interstellar medium has a significant effect on the evolution of their host Galaxy. Yet despite on-going efforts, their formation remains poorly understood due to the rarity of their progenitors. This proposal aims to advance this understanding by targeting four newly-identified high-mass cores at the Galactic centre. These cores all contain > 100 Msun within < 0.2 pc and are young - all prime candidates for representing the initial conditions of the most massive stars. Furthermore, each core displays differing amounts of star-formation activity, potentially providing a unique evolutionary sequence of massive star formation under the same environmental conditions. ALMA's unparalleled sensitivity at high angular resolution will allow us to resolve the physical and kinematic structures within these cores down to 1000 AU. These data will provide the ultimate test for star formation theories in such extreme regimes and allow us to place constraints on the dominant physical mechanisms governing the formation of the most massive stars.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysics Research Institute, Liverpool John Moores University
